data.title: Start Monodroid MonoGame from a thread causes exception
Songs not loading on Windows (Compressed or not)
data.body:
Loading a song the way it would load on XNA, throws an NotSupportedException "Specified stream is not a wave file.";

The content folder contains what XNA usually builds, a small .xnb file and a .wma song.

Song tries to load the file as a plain WAV file, but it is a .wma and crashes.

I know compressed songs are not supported yet, but until now, maybe the content processor should create a plain wave file that could be read. My inputs are WAV files anyway ( We use a XACT project on XBLIG games ).

data.title: Small fixes for input and storage
data.body: And a rather dirty fix for int support in shaders (because it just casts them to floats)

data.title: Windows: StorageDevice not working
Unhandled error when Dispose in Monodroid
Windows Phone 8 Support (Test Me)
data.body:
This is the initial pull of WP8 support.

We should double check that I didn't break any other platforms.

WP8 projects will automatically pull in some XNA assembly references which conflict with MonoGame.  To fix this add the following MSBuild commands to the bottom of your .CSPROJ file right below the `<Import>` lines:

```
  <Target Name="MonoGame_RemoveXnaAssemblies" AfterTargets="ImplicitlyExpandTargetFramework">
    <Message Text="MonoGame - Removing XNA Assembly references!" Importance="normal"/>
    <ItemGroup>
      <ReferencePath Remove="@(ReferencePath)" Condition="'%(Filename)%(Extension)'=='Microsoft.Xna.Framework.dll'" />
      <ReferencePath Remove="@(ReferencePath)" Condition="'%(Filename)%(Extension)'=='Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamerServices.dll'" />
      <ReferencePath Remove="@(ReferencePath)" Condition="'%(Filename)%(Extension)'=='Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamerServicesExtensions.dll'" />
      <ReferencePath Remove="@(ReferencePath)" Condition="'%(Filename)%(Extension)'=='Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.dll'" />
      <ReferencePath Remove="@(ReferencePath)" Condition="'%(Filename)%(Extension)'=='Microsoft.Xna.Framework.MediaLibraryExtensions.dll'" />
    </ItemGroup>
  </Target>
```

This will be added to the MonoGame WP8 template projects once we get those in place.

data.title: Initial cut of a F# based project template for MonoGame on the Mac
data.body:
There is currently two caveats:
1) When a new project is created the logo.png file under the Content directory has no build action.  The build action for this file needs to be changed to copy to output
2) The References Lidgren.Network.dll and MonoGame.FrameWork.MacOS.dll are not referenced correctly, I think this is a issue because I have not installed MonoGame as a package.

data.title: Some shader related fixes and additions
MGFX: Sampler states are not stored / loaded with the effect.
data.body: Looks like MGFX doesn't apply sampler states to effects, always defaulting to linear clamp or something like that. Not sure though.

data.title: MGFX: Strange behavior with a rather simple shader
MGFX: Setting int parameters not supported
data.body: ConstantBuffer throws an exception when trying to set an integer shader parameter (only floats are supported).

data.title: Could not create OpenGLES 2.0 frame buffer Exception
data.body:
Hello, I'm getting the following error when I try and just run the basic XNA Windows Game application in the Android emulator.  If I just create a new vanilla OpenGL Android For Mono Application that works fine though.  So the steps I'm following are:

Create a new solution, starting with a XNA Game Studio 4.0 - Windows Game (4.0) project.  Don't change it at all; if I run it I just get a window with a blue background.

I then add a new OpenGL Android For Mono Application and set it as the startup project.  To this project I add the Lidgren.Network.Android (v2011.3.12.0), MonoGame.Framework.Android (v2.0.0.0 from the new v3.0 Beta download), and Tao.Sdl (v1.2.13.0) references.  I then do an Add As Link on the WindowsGame1's Game1.cs file.
## Next I change the Activity1.cs file to this:

using System;

using Android.App;
using Android.Content;
using Android.Runtime;
using Android.Views;
using Android.Widget;
using Android.OS;

namespace OpenGLApplication1
{
    [Activity(Label = "OpenGLApplication1", MainLauncher = true, Icon = "@drawable/icon")]
    public class Activity1 : Microsoft.Xna.Framework.AndroidGameActivity
    {
        GLView1 view;

```
    protected override void OnCreate(Bundle bundle)
    {
        base.OnCreate(bundle);

        WindowsGame1.Game1.Activity = this;
        var game = new WindowsGame1.Game1();
        SetContentView(game.Window);
        game.Run();
    }
}
```
## }
## When I try and run the application in the Android emulator (API v14) I get an exception when it loads, with the following output to the debug window:

data.title: Removed unnecessary update of previous location to fix issue #927
data.body:
Fix for issue https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/927

Updating the touch's previous location within TouchLocation.AsMovedState results in doubly updating the previous location in each update loop, which means the previous location is always the same as the current one. 

To fix this, we removed the update within TouchLocation.AsMovedState. I have tested this on the Surface and it has fixed our issue. Also ran the TouchInput Sample (the one with the cat sprites) and it functions correctly after this change.

data.title: Fix for #922 and Project template Fixes
data.body:
This PR has a fix for #922 in which setting the InactiveSleepTime throws an exception. This usually comes up when porting a Windows Phone 7 game to Windows 8, but results in a weird error from the Helper class to create the game rather than the NotImplementedException. 

The other changes are to the projects to hopefully fix some of the references issues. Also changes to the MonoDevelop addin to allow the runtime to be deployed with the AddIn on Mac and Linux. This will remove the need for an installer for those platforms.

data.title: Fixes bug when trying to load a Song that's right inside Content's folder.
data.body: If you put a Song (wmb + xnb) inside the Content's folder, the CurrentAssetDirectory is used with the ContentManager.RootDirectory at SongReader's Read method, merging them and causing it to use the wrong path. I've tested this only on Windows8, so probably need to test this on other platforms too to make sure this is not a Windows8 bug only.

data.title: [Windows 8] Texture2D.GetData not returning all pixel color data in Monogame 3 (BETA) with "VisualStudio 2012 for Windows 8" "Game" template
[Windows 8] Reference SplashScreen and SettingsPane
data.body:
Currently there is no way to access the SplashScreen from the game class. It involves a little bit of hacking, as we only receive its reference in the XAML's LaunchedEventArgs.
This is important because if we want correct loading behaviour, we need the Dismissed event of the SplashScreen. I think there should be a universal way to access it.
SettingsPane could also be referenced somewhere, but it is less of an issue as it can be accessed from CoreWindow.

data.title: Various Windows 8 related fixes
data.body:
Fixes #899
Fixes #923 (assuming we set the MediaState correclty)
Fixes strange behaviour of Windows 8 trial
Reworked messagebox for correct behaviour
Moved the IsVisible sets to the delegates so the Guide won't get stuck if the EndShow functions are not called

data.title: Android - fixed memory usage in Texture2D
data.body:
We were having lots of memory issues with our Android port, our game would get an OutOfMemoryException when loading textures.  It would happen on certain devices, and could sometimes get alleviated by calling GC.Collect() (which I didn't like).  It would always happen when trying to load my first 2048x2048 sprite sheet.

So to fix it, I added using statements and a call to Recycle() on any Bitmap object in Texture2D.  I removed the use of MemoryStream and read from the original Stream directly.  I also used the appropriate BitmapOptions we are using in other apps for better memory performance.

These changes are now working in our game (Draw a Stickman: EPIC http://epic.drawastickman.com), and I want to contribute back. 

Let's just make sure I didn't break something for someone else.

MonoGame is great, keep up the good work.

data.title: VertexBuffer.GetData<T>(T[] ) crashes when asking for byte[]
Fix for VertexBuffer.GetData<T>() so it works with sizes smaller than the vertex stride
data.body:
It's iterating through all the vertex count, so it's slow, but at least it works...

Please be kind, it's my first pull request attempt ;)

data.title: VertexBuffer.GetData crashes when asking for a certain component
Bug in GetPreviousLocation for TouchLocation
data.body:
Hi Tom, 

There is a bug we are seeing with the previous location code for TouchLocations. I know you didn't want to see a full rewrite of the touch code, so I will describe the issue here:

The bug we are seeing is that the previous location for all TouchLocations is always the same as the current location. This is because within each update loop of the game, TouchLocations save off their previous location twice, resulting in it simply being equal to the current location.

In TouchPanel.RefreshState, the first time around we call touch.UpdateState which updates the previous location. This sets the stateChanged flag, which then means we will go through the RefreshState one more time because of the loop in TouchPanel.GetState. In this second pass, we have no more events for that touch point, so touchEvent is false, and touch.AsMovedState is called. This also contains code which also saves off the previous location.

I believe the previous location saving should only be in one place or the other.

This was tested on the Surface RT Windows 8.

Thanks!

data.title: Issue similar to #916 Loading Effect Windows8
Visual Studio 2012 Express Projects Not Appearing
data.body:
I installed MonoGame with the Visual Studio 2012 templates on. I see that it made a folder in my "Visual Studio 2012\Templates\ProjectTemplates\Visual C#\MonoGame" folder, but Visual Studios 2012 Express doesn't see them when creating a new project. 

I then put the Visual Studios 2010 templates from "Visual Studio 2010\Templates\ProjectTemplates\Visual C#\MonoGame" into the 2012 folder. It worked and they appeared in Visual Studios 2012 Express.

data.title: Develop3d
[WinRT] SoundManager bugs
data.body:
I'm not really into the WinRT sound manager, so I'll just leave these here:

PlayPosition is missing.
Pause function does not check if there is any song played so it can turn the MediaState into Paused without anything to pause (normally it should stay on stopped if there is nothing to play).

data.title: Crashing on TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1)
WaveBank.cs does not support MiniFormatTag_ADPCM
data.body: For full compatibility, the above will need to be implemented.

data.title: 3D depth buffer seems stuck at 16 bits on Windows
data.body:
My 3D app, originally written in XNA, needs a 24-bit depth buffer and it worked fine in XNA.  After porting to MonoGame it's behaving as though the depth buffer is locked at 16-bits because I get a lot of z-fighting that looks pretty much like what I get with the XNA version if I request a 16-bit depth buffer.  With MonoGame, even if I request DepthFormat.None it still behaves like it's using a 16-bit buffer rather than no buffer at all.

Using 3.0 beta (updated 10/25) on Windows 7, Visual Studio 2010.
